journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: H∞ controller design for a class of switched linear discrete-time system with polytopic uncertainties

article-meta.aff: 1School of Transportation and Logistics, Southwest Jiaotong University, People’s Republic of China
2School of Electrical Engineering, Southwest Jiaotong University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Weiming Xiang, School of Electrical Engineering, Southwest Jiaotong University, No. 111, Erhuanlu Beiyiduan, Chengdu, Sichuan 610031, People’s Republic of China. Email: xwm1004@163.com; xiangweiming@swust.edu.cn

abstract.p: In this article, a new parameter-dependent stability criterion for switched linear discrete-time systems with polytopic uncertainties is provided to correct an error occurring in previous work, and the parameter-dependent idea is extended to ℓ2 gain analysis problem. Particularly, a less conservative result is proposed by introducing additional slack matrices. Furthermore, the ℋ∞ control problem is investigated. Due to the online calculation characteristic of parameter-dependent controller, a controller structure with less computation cost is of interest. Aside from the controller with the same form as in some existing results involving matrix multiplication and inversion operators, another simple structure of controller formulated by a convex combination of a set of matrices is proposed, which can reduce the online computation cost significantly. A numerical example and results of simulation performed on the model of two-mass-spring mechanical system are provided to illustrate the theoretical findings within this article.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Switched systems have emerged as an important class and represent a relatively new and very active area of current research in the field of control systems. A switched system is composed of a family of continuous or discrete-time subsystems, described by differential or difference equations, respectively, along with a switching rule governing the switching between the subsystems. Switched system can be efficiently used to model many practical systems that are inherently multimodel in the sense that several dynamical subsystem models are required to describe their behavior. Several real-world and industrial processes exhibit switched and hybrid nature intrinsically.1–3 Switched systems arise in many engineering applications, such as in motor engine control,4 constrained robotics,5 and networked control systems,6 and so on. Furthermore, more and more industrial applications resort to switching strategy to improve control performance.7–10 In general, stability and stabilization problems are the main concerns in the field of switched systems. Lyapunov function techniques have been proved to be effective to deal with stability and stabilization problems for switched systems.10–14 Dwell time and average dwell time approach have been employed to deal with the stability and stabilization of time-dependent switched systems.15–18 For more details of the recent results on the basic problems in stability and stabilization for switched systems, the reader is referred to the study of Lin et al.,19 and the references cited therein.

On the other hand, the uncertainties inevitably exist in most practical systems; a number of results have been reported to address system analysis and synthesis problems with uncertainties such as the studies by Wu and Ho20 and Shen et al.21 However, from the authors’ best knowledge, the control problem on uncertain switched systems has not been fully investigated yet, especially for the H∞ control problem for switched systems using parameter-dependent ideas. In the study by Zhang et al.,11 by using a parameter-dependent idea, a stability criterion is proposed based on switched parameter-dependent quadratic Lyapunov function (SPDQLF), which successfully reduces the conservativeness in contrast to other Lyapunov function approaches such as switched quadratic Lyapunov function (SQLF) and common quadratic Lyapunov function (CQLF) approaches. However, it has to be pointed out that an error occurs in the derivation process, which directly leads to the incorrectness of the stability criterion proposed in the Zhang et al. study.11 In short, the time-varying uncertain parameters are wrongly supposed to maintain a time-invariant value, which obviously contradicts the parameter-dependent idea in the Zhang et al. study.11 In this article, this error will be clarified in detail and corrected later on.

The main contributions of this article are two-fold. First, the error in the Zhang et al. study11 is explained and a corrected parameter-dependent stability criterion is established. Afterward, the parameter-dependent idea will be extended to ℓ2 gain performance analysis problem. Especially, it has to be mentioned that by introducing additional slack matrices, the conservativeness in the ℓ2 gain analysis can be reduced to some extent, and it plays an important role in solving the following controller design problem by proposing a method with less computation cost. Second, the H∞ control problem is studied based on the stability and ℓ2 gain analysis results. Due to the parameter-dependent idea, the designed controller is also parameter-dependent, which certainly requires the online measurement of uncertain parameters and an online calculation for parameter-dependent controller at each instant. Naturally, due to the online calculation characteristic and in order to make sure the designed controller can be used widely and can be easily applied to actual applications, the selection of a controller with less computation cost is of great significance and interest. In this article, aside from the controller with the same structure given in the study of Zhang et al.,11 which involves matrix multiplication and inversion operators, a new structure for the parameter-dependent controller formulated as a simple convex combination of a set of matrices is proposed, which can reduce the online computation cost significantly.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. In the “Problem formulation and preliminaries” section, problem description and some preliminaries are introduced; the asymptotic stability and ℓ2 gain analysis are proposed in the “Stability and ℓ2 gain performance analysis” section. In section “H∞ controller design,” the H∞ control synthesis problem is investigated. In section “Design example,” a numerical design example is presented. Conclusions are given in the “Conclusions” section.

sec.title: Problem formulation and preliminaries
sec.p: In this article, a class of uncertain switched linear discrete-time systems is given in the following form
where x(k)∈ℝnx is the state, u(k)∈ℝnu is the control input, ω(k)∈ℝnω is an exogenous disturbance, which belongs to ℓ2[0,∞), that is, it satisfies

where d>0. z(k)∈ℝnz is the controlled output vector. σ(k):ℤ+→I:={1,2,…,N} is a piecewise constant function of time, called switching law or switching signal, which takes value in a finite index set I:={1,2,…,N}. N>0 is the number of subsystems. As in most reported literature, the value of σ(k) is not known a priori, but its instantaneous value is available real time.
For each i∈I, we have
denoting the ith subsystems with partially unknown parameters. It is assumed that
where ℜi is a given convex bounded polyhedral domain described as

where λ=[λ1λ2⋯λs] denotes the uncertain parameters, s denotes the number of vertices. Matrices Ai,m, Bi,1,m, Bi,2,m, Ci,m, Di,1,m, and Di,2,m are real known constant matrices with appropriate dimensions denoting the mth vertex in the ith subsystem. Without loss of generality, the number of vertices in each subsystem is assumed to be equal here.

Our objective in this article is to derive sufficient conditions to ensure the asymptotic stability and the required ℓ2 gain performance, and to further apply them into H∞ control synthesis problems. Here, it should be pointed out that there exist some results on stability criterion for switched discrete-time systems with polytopic uncertainties, especially, the recent results from the SPDQLF approach proposed in the Zhang et al. study,11 which shows less conservatism in contrast to the CQLF and SQLF approaches. However, it has to be pointed out that an error occurs in the stability criterion of the SPDQLF approach of Zhang et al.,11 which will be shown later. Thus, in this article, initially we will establish the corrected stability criterion using the SPDQLF idea, then extend the results to ℓ2 gain performance, which is defined as follows:
Given a scalar γ>0 and u(k)=0, find sufficient conditions such that:

list-item.p: the system (1) is asymptotically stable when ω(k)=0;
under zero initial condition, the following ℓ2 gain performance specified condition is satisfied

sec.title: Stability and ℓ2 gain performance analysis
sec.p: In this section, first, the idea of SPDQLF will be introduced and an error in the Zhang et al. study11 will be pointed out. Then, the corrected parameter-dependent stability criterion will be proposed. Finally, the parameter-dependent idea will be extended to the ℓ2 gain performance analysis problem.

sec.title: Previous work
sec.p: In the recent article by Zhang et al,11 a stability criterion based on SPDQLF approach was proposed, and it was proved that the conservativeness was significantly reduced by using SPDQLF. In this section, we will extend the results to ℓ2 gain performance on the basis of SPDQLF. Before presenting our results, the idea of SPDQLF will be briefly introduced, and the error in the previous work has to be pointed out. First, the unforced switched linear discrete-time system is considered
From the idea of the SPDQLF approach as proposed in the Zhang et al. study,11 we have to find an SPDQLF as follows
where Pi(λ)=∑m=1sλmPi,m and Pi,m>0 to guarantee that the following condition is satisfied, which plays a crucial role in stability analysis

where λ+=[λ1+λ2+⋯λs+] denotes the value of λ at discrete-time k+1. It should be mentioned that λ+≠λ since λ is considered as a time-varying parameter. The main aim is to find sufficient conditions to ensure that the following condition is satisfied

list-item.p: Remark 1. In the Zhang et al. study,11 it was supposed that λ+ has a same value of uncertain parameter λ at discrete-time k, that is, λ+=λ. For example, by the proof line of Theorem 1 in the study of Zhang et al.,11 we see that

sec.p: which is derived based on λ+=λ. However, we usually have λ+≠λ, since the uncertain parameters λ are essentially time-varying variables, not time-invariant variables. For instance, in the two-mass-spring mechanical system example proposed by Zhang et al.,11 which will be again used later in this article, the uncertain parameter is the varying spring constant, which is time-varying and required to be measured online at each discrete step to formulate the controller. Hence, we cannot derive equation (9), which directly leads to incorrectness of the main results in the Zhang et al. study.11 Similar mistakes also occur in the controller design results of the Zhang et al. study.11

Obviously, the stability criterion derived based on equation (8) with λ+≠λ will be different from that based on λ+=λ, which establishes an incorrect stability criterion for switched system (5). In the next subsection, we will find a new corrected stability criterion on the basis of equation (8).

sec.title: Stability criterion
sec.p: Now, we shall present our first result on asymptotic stability condition of unforced uncertain switched system (5) based on SPDQLF (6).

list-item.p: Theorem 1. Consider uncertain switched system (5). If there exist positive matrices Pi,l>0, ∀i∈I, l={1,…,s} such that for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and m,l={1,…,s} the following conditions are satisfied

sec.p: Then, uncertain switched system (5) is asymptotically stable.

list-item.p: Proof. By constructing a SPDQLF as

sec.p: where Pi(λ)=∑m=1sλmPi,m and Pi,m>0, we can derive that ∀(i,j)∈I×I

In equation (12), the case i=j shows that the switched system (1) works in the ith mode, and the case i≠j implies the switched system (5) is switching from subsystem i to j from switching instant k to k+1. It should be mentioned that whatever the case i=j or i≠j, the value of uncertain variable λ+ determined at instant k+1 may be different from the value of λ at discrete-time k.
Thus, we have
By simple computation, we can derive the following equation
Then, from condition (10), for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and ∀m,n,l∈{1,…,s}, the following results can be obtained
Moreover, since Pj,l>0, we have
which gives
From equations (15) and (17), we get
Hence, altogether from equations (15) and (18), it is obvious that equation (14) forward to ΔV<0, which completes the proof. ■

Theorem 1 provides us a corrected stability criterion for an uncertain switched system (5) based on SPDQLF. Similarly as in Zhang et al.’s study,11 if matrices Pi,l=Pi and further Pi,l=P are selected, we will obtain the corresponding stability criteria based on SQLF and CQLF, respectively, which is stated by the following corollaries.

list-item.p: Corollary 1. Consider an uncertain switched system (5). If there exist positive matrices Pi>0, ∀i∈I such that for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and m={1,…,s} the following conditions are satisfied

sec.p: Then, there exist an SQLF V(xk)=xkTPixk ensuring uncertain switched system (5) asymptotically stable.

list-item.p: Corollary 2. Consider uncertain switched system (5). If there exist positive matrices P>0 such that for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and m={1,…,s} the following conditions are satisfied

sec.p: Then, there exist a CQLF V(xk)=xkTPxk ensuring uncertain switched system (5) asymptotically stable.

list-item.p: Remark 2. Although Theorem 1 of Zhang et al.11 is incorrect, as the time-varying property of the uncertain parameter λ is forgotten by the authors, the Corollaries 1 and 2 proposed by them are still correct, which actually are the same as Corollaries 1 and 2 in this article, since both SQLF and CQLF are constructed independently with the uncertain parameter λ.

sec.title: l2gain performance
sec.p: In this section, based on the stability results in the previous section, the ℓ2 gain performance is considered, which is concerned with following uncertain switched system subjected to disturbances
where disturbance ω(k) satisfies equation (2). Based on the SPDQLF approach, the following theorem can be derived.

list-item.p: Theorem 2. Consider uncertain switched system (19). Given a scalar γ>0, if there exist positive matrices Pi,l>0, ∀i∈I, l={1,…,s} such that for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and m,l={1,…,s} the following conditions are satisfied

sec.p: Then, the uncertain switched system (19) is asymptotically stable when ω(k)=0 and has a prescribed ℓ2 gain performance index γ when x(0)=0.

where ΔV defines the difference of V along the solution of system (19).
One has

Hence, by V(K)≥0, we can derive

Then, JK can be rewritten as follows

list-item.p: Remark 3. Similar to stability analysis problems, when Pi,l=Pi and further Pi,l=P are chosen, the sufficient conditions based on SQLF and CQLF can be obtained as follows

sec.p: which can guarantee the ℓ2 gain performance of switched system (19); however, more conservativeness is brought in by equations (27) and (28).

list-item.p: Remark 4. Based on Theorem 1, optimization problem minγ2 subjected to equation (20) can be formulated to compute the minimal ℓ2 gain performance index γ, that is, the minimal disturbance attenuation index γ of switched system (19).

sec.p: Based on Theorem 2, another sufficient condition can be derived as follows, which will be essential in state feedback controller design later on.

list-item.p: Theorem 3. Consider uncertain switched system (19). Given a scalar γ>0, if there exist positive matrices Qi,l>0 and nonsingular matrices Wi,l, ∀i∈I, l={1,…,s} such that for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and m,n,l={1,…,s} the following conditions are satisfied

sec.p: Then, the uncertain switched system (19) is asymptotically stable when ω(k)=0 and has a prescribed ℓ2 gain performance index γ when x(0)=0.

list-item.p: Proof. Suppose equation (29) holds, we can obtain (Qi,m−Wi,n)TQi,m−1(Qi,m−Wi,n)≥0, so the following inequality can be derived

sec.p: Therefore, equation (29) yields that
Premultiplying diag{Wi,n−T,I,I,I} and postmultiplying diag{Wi,n−1,I,I,I}, one can obtain
Then, letting Pi,m=Qi,m−1 and Pj,l−1=Qj,l, it arrives
which, by Schur complement lemma, is equivalent to
Through the results in Theorem 2, the proof completes. ■

list-item.p: Remark 5. With the addition of new slack matrices Wi,m, sufficient conditions to make the matrices Pj,l not involved in any product with Ai,m and Bi,m are derived, which makes the state feedback controller design feasible. Furthermore, since the slack matrices Wi,m are introduced in Theorem 3, more parameters are included in the linear matrix inequalities (LMIs), which implies extra degrees of freedom are introduced than Theorem 2, which possibly reduces conservativeness. It is noted that the introduced matrices Wi,m are not even constrained to be symmetric. This result will play a crucial role for a new type of state feedback controller design with less online computation cost later on.

sec.p: In the Zhang et al. study,11 it is demonstrated by numerical examples that SPDQLF is less conservative than SQLF and CQLF in the stability analysis problem. Similarly, in the ℓ2 gain performance analysis problem, SPDQLF has advantages as well; moreover, as the statements in Remark 5, the introduction of slack matrices Wi,m can further reduce the conservativeness. These points are illustrated by following numerical example.

list-item.p: Example 1. Consider the uncertain switched system (19) consisting of two subsystems, and the vertices of subsystems are given as follows

sec.p: The objective in this example is to find the minimal value of disturbance attenuation index γ, that is, the ℓ2 gain performance index γ. The calculation results from different approaches are shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Different value of γ by different approaches

fn.p: SQLF: switched quadratic Lyapunov function; CQLF: common quadratic Lyapunov function.

sec.p: In Table 1, obviously, Theorems 2 and 3 show less conservativeness than the other two approaches based on SQLF and CQLF, respectively, which implies that the SPDQLF approach can reduce the conservativeness. Moreover, comparing the results of Theorems 2 and 3, we can see that Theorem 3 has less conservativeness because of the introduction of the additional slack matrices Wi,m as in Remark 5.

Furthermore, actually the disturbance attenuation properties are allowed to be different subsystems such as in Table 2. For instance, the ℓ2 gain performance index γ for subsystems 1 and 2 are calculated as 0.1603 and 0.3561, respectively. However, it is interesting to see that, if there exists switching behavior between these two subsystems, the ℓ2 gain performance of each subsystem cannot be maintained. In other words, the ℓ2 gain performance is deteriorated by switching behavior among subsystems. Therefore, the ℓ2 gain performance in the presence of switching deserves our investigation.

caption.p: Different value of γ of different subsystems

sec.title:
ℋ
∞
controller design
sec.p: Motivated by the SPDQLF approach given in the previous section, the state feedback controller for the polytopic uncertain switched system (1) is of the following form

Here, it is assumed that the switching signal of switched system (1) is available online and the corresponding state feedback controller of each subsystem can be activated synchronously. Thus, by applying (30) into system (1), the corresponding closed-loop system becomes
where A¯σ(k)(λ)=Aσ(k)(λ)+Bσ(k),2(λ)Kσ(k)(λ) and C¯σ(k)(λ)=Cσ(k)(λ)+Dσ(k),2(λ)Kσ(k)(λ). The H∞ control problem can be formulated as follows:

sec.title:
ℋ
∞
control problem
sec.p: Given a scalar γ>0, design a state feedback switched parameter-dependent controller (30) such that the close-loop system (31) is asymptotically stable when ω(k)=0 and has an ℓ2 gain performance index γ when x(0)=0.

In the Zhang et al. study,11 however, the switched stabilizing controller is designed similar to the approach used in the stability analysis problem, and the same error that the uncertain parameter λ is mistaken as a time-invariant variable occurs in the controller design process. Here, based on Theorems 2 and 3, the state feedback H∞ controller will be designed. Particularly, in the Zhang et al. study,11 a switched parameter-dependent controller in the structure is given by

In this article, we will follow the controller structure (32) and propose a controller with Ki(λ) as above, but there exist some drawbacks in actual applications, which will be explained in detail later on. Thus, another simple controller structure is presented in the form of

Obviously, comparing controller structure (33) with (32), the online computation cost within (33), which only contains a convex combination without any matrix multiplication and inversion operations such as in equation (32), is reduced significantly and can be easily applied to meet the requirement of practical systems. Hence, equation (33) is much more suitable and applicable in actual practices. Both equations (32) and (33) will be investigated and compared in this section. At first, a state feedback controller with the form of equation (32) is presented by following theorem.

list-item.p: Theorem 4. Consider uncertain switched system (1). Given a scalar γ>0, if there exist positive matrices Qi,l>0 and matrices Ui,l, ∀i∈I, l={1,…,s} such that for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and m,n,l={1,…,s} the following conditions are satisfied

sec.p: where
Then, the closed-loop system (31) is asymptotically stable when ω(k)=0 and has a prescribed ℓ2 gain performance index γ when x(0)=0 with state feedback control given by
where Ui(λ)=∑m=1sλmUi,m and Qi(λ)=∑m=1sλmQi,m.

list-item.p: Proof. Let Ξi,j(λ)=∑l=1s∑m=1s∑n=1sλl+λmλnΞl,m,ni,j where Ξl,m,ni,j is same as in equation (34). From equation (34), it is easy to see that

sec.p: By choosing Ui(λ)=∑m=1sλmUi,m, Qi(λ)=∑m=1sλmQi,m, Qj(λ+)=∑l=1sλl+Qj,l and using Ui(λ)=Ki(λ)Qi(λ), equation (36) becomes
where A¯i(λ) and C¯i(λ) are defined same as in equation (31). Pre- and postmultiplying diag{Qi−1(λ),I,I,I}, and further letting Qj(λ+)=Pj−1(λ+) and Qi−1(λ)=Pi(λ), we obtain
which, according to Schur complement lemma, is equivalent to
where Ω¯i11(λ)=A¯iT(λ)Pj(λ+)A¯i(λ)−Pi(λ)+C¯iT(λ)C¯i(λ), Ω¯i12(λ)=A¯iT(λ)Pj(λ+)Bi(λ)+C¯iT(λ)Di(λ), and Ω¯i22(λ)=BiT(λ)Pj(λ+)Bi(λ)+DiT(λ)Di(λ)−γ2I.
Thus, following the same guideline in Theorem 2, it is proved that
which directly leads to JK<0 defined same as equation (21), which thus implies that the closed-loop system (31) is asymptotically stable with a prescribed ℓ2 gain performance index γ. ■

By the structure of equation (32), similar to that used by Zhang et al. in their study,11 the derivation of controller (32) is on the basis of the switched parameter-dependent idea, which implies that the solution of the stabilizing state feedback controller is dependent on the uncertain parameter λ. By the online measurement of the parameter λ, the controller gain can be calculated according to equation (30) at each discrete-time instant k. The algorithm for the controller implementation is proposed in the following.

sec.title: Algorithm 1

list-item.p: Step 1: Solve the LMIs (34) to obtain Ui,m and Qi,m offline based on Theorem 4.
Step 2: Measure the switching signal σ(k), value of uncertain parameter λ and the system state x(t) real time.
Step 3: Calculate out the controller gains Ki(λ)=(∑m=1sλmUi,m)(∑m=1sλmQi,m)−1 based on Theorem 4.
Step 4: Apply u(k)=Kσ(k)(λ)x(k) to the uncertain switched system (1).
Step 5: k←k+1 and go to Step 2.

Remark 6. Obviously, it requires that the exact value of time-varying uncertain parameter λ must be measurable in practice, and the controller would work well if the controller gain can be calculated out in time by Algorithm 1, but in actual practice the structure of equation (32) shows its drawbacks and limits. If the system order is high, implying the dimensions of corresponding matrices Ui,m and Qi,m are large, the online calculation of controller Ki(λ)=Ui(λ)Qi−1(λ) will represent significant computation difficulties since it contains the matrix multiplication and inversion operators, which requires huge online computation cost when the matrix dimensions are large. Hence, if we consider the high-order switched system, the state feedback controller in Algorithm 1 may not be calculated out in time to meet the requirement of practical systems.

sec.p: To avoid the huge computation cost problem for high-order switched system, a simple structure of state feedback controller (33) is considered. Applying equation (33) into system (31), the closed-loop system becomes
where, for any σ(k)=i, A¯i(λ) and C¯i(λ) are defined as follows
where A¯i,mn=Ai,m+Bi,2,mKi,n and C¯i,mn=Ci,m+Di,2,mKi,n. Then, based on Theorem 3, the following results can be derived.

list-item.p: Theorem 5. Consider uncertain switched system (1). Given a scalar γ>0, if there exist positive matrices Qi,l>0, matrices Ui,l and nonsingular matrices Wi,l∀i∈I, l={1,…,s} such that for ∀(i,j)∈I×I and m,n,l={1,…,s} the following conditions are satisfied

sec.p: where
Then, the closed-loop system (38) is asymptotically stable when ω(k)=0 and has a prescribed ℓ2 gain performance index γ when x(0)=0 with state feedback control given by
where Ki,n=Ui,nWi,n−1.

list-item.p: Proof. Substituting Ui,n=Ki,nWi,n into equation (39), and by A¯i,mn=Ai,m+Bi,2,mKi,n and C¯i,mn=Ci,m+Di,2,mKi,n, it turns into

sec.p: Then, from Theorem 3, it implies the closed-loop system (38) is asymptotically stable with a prescribed ℓ2 gain performance index γ. ■
Based on Theorem 5, the algorithm for controller implementation is proposed in the following.

list-item.p: Step 1: Solve the controller gains Ki,n=Ui,nWi,n−1 offline based on Theorem 5.
Step 2: Measure the switching signal σ(k), value of uncertain parameter λ and the system state x(t) real time.
Step 3: Calculate the corresponding controller gains Ki(λ)=∑n=1sλnKi,n online.
Step 4: Apply u(k)=Kσ(k)(λ)x(k) to the uncertain switched system (1).
Step 5: k←k+1 and go to Step 2.

Remark 7. To clarify the advantages of Algorithm 2, a necessary comparison between design Algorithms 1 and 2 is addressed here. In contrast to Algorithm 1, we see that the online calculation in Algorithm 2 is only a convex combination of a set of matrices, which have already been calculated offline in step 1. Thus, the online computation cost is reduced significantly, which implies that Algorithm 2 is much more suitable and applicable in practice. Moreover, since Algorithm 2 is formulated on the basis of Theorem 5, which is essentially derived from Theorem 3, according to Remark 5, it shows less conservativeness than Algorithm 1 based on Theorem 4, which is derived from Theorem 2. A numerical comparison between the two structures of controllers will be given later in this article.

Remark 8. Similar to the statement in Remark 4, we can formulate the following optimization problems: minγ2 subjected to equation (34) or (39) to obtain optimal state feedback controller with minimal performance index γ.

Remark 9: Through similar techniques as that used by Zhang et al,11 our results can be extended to a slow-switched system in the framework of the average dwell time approach. Here, it has to be pointed out that the error that occurs because the uncertain parameter λ is considered as a time-invariant variable occurs in the slow-switching case of the Zhang et al. study as well. This should be corrected in the same way as explained in this article.

sec.title: Design example
sec.p: In this section, a similar mechanical system borrowed from Zhang et al.’s study11 is used to validate our results. Consider the two-mass-spring system with an exogenous disturbance input ω along with the input u shown as in Figure 1.
By the sampling time of 0.1 s, the discrete-time state–space system can be described as follows
where
and uncertain parameter θ stands for the varying spring constant, which is assumed to belong to [Kmin,Kmax] with Kmin=0.5 and Kmax=15. The output is assumed to be z(k)=Cx(k), where C=[1100].

By the idea of partitioning the varying parameter θ into three scopes as Sc1=[0.5,5], Sc2=[5,10], and Sc3=[10,15], the linear parameter-varying (LPV) system can be represented as a switched system (1) with three subsystems and two vertices as follows by choosing m1=m2=1
Both Algorithms 1 and 2 are applied to derive the state feedback controller to achieve a minimal value of gain performance index γ, which is presented in Table 3.

caption.p: Minimal value of γ by Algorithms 1 and 2

sec.p: Obviously, Theorem 5 has less conservativeness than Theorem 4 since it has much smaller value of γ. Then, the online computation cost including the minimal, maximal, average calculation time for the corresponding controller at each discrete step, and the total time of computation cost during the simulation time [0,200] is shown in Table 4.

From Table 4, the advantage of Algorithm 2 is obvious since Algorithm 2 represents much less computation cost than Algorithm 1 during the simulation interval. Thus, we adopt Algorithm 2 here. The variation of the uncertain parameter θ is randomly generated and can be measured instantaneously as in Figure 2, and the corresponding switching signal is generated as in Figure 3.

Given the initial state x0=[1100], the state response without exogenous disturbance is given in Figure 4. By the simulation curves in Figure 4, we see that the closed-loop system without disturbance is asymptotically stable. Then, we consider the exogenous disturbance assumed to be ω(k)=5r/(15k+1), where r is a random number taken from a uniform distribution over [0,1], the output response under zero initial condition is given in Figure 5.

It is easy to calculate that the disturbance ∑k=0∞ωT(k)ω(k)≈∑k=0200ωT(k)ω(k)=0.0228, and the output response ∑k=0∞zT(k)z(k)≈∑k=0200zT(k)z(k)=2.6039×10−6. It is obvious that equation (4) is satisfied with γ=0.0261.

Therefore, from the simulation results in Figures 4 and 5, we can conclude that the parameter-dependent controller designed according to Algorithm 2 works efficiently to meet the required H∞ control performance.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the stability, ℓ2 gain analysis, and H∞ control problems for a class of switched linear discrete-time systems with polytopic uncertainties are studied. At first, by pointing out an error result occurring in the previous work, a corrected stability criterion is presented. Then, the parameter-dependent idea is extended to the ℓ2 gain analysis problem. By introducing additional slack matrices, a less conservative sufficient condition is derived for a prescribed ℓ2 gain. Based on the results in the analysis part, the H∞ control problem is addressed. Aside from the controller structure proposed in the previous work, another controller with simpler structure and less computation cost is proposed, which is a convex combination of a set of matrices and can reduce the computation cost significantly. Numerical and laboratory mechanical model examples are provided to illustrate our results in this article. Furthermore, the approach proposed in this article to deal with the time-varying polytopic uncertainties can be easily extended to scheduling parameters, where the switched linear parameter-varying system is going to be considered.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: The notations used in this article are fairly standard. The superscript “T” stands for matrix transposition. ℝn denotes the n dimensional Euclidean space and ℤ+ represents the set of nonnegative integers. I:={1,2,…,N} is the finite index set. In addition, in symmetric block matrices, we use * as an ellipsis for the terms that are introduced by symmetry and diag{⋯} stands for a block-diagonal matrix. The notation P>0 (P≥0) means P is real symmetric and positive definite (semi-positive definite).
